author: mike.ferris
content: <@!364458974906548225> kind of bikeshedding here, but why call them "overlay" network and "content" network when they both seem to be overlay networks? If i'm understanding correctly they could instead be called "routing-overlay" and "content-overlay"

author: pipermerriam
content:
The distinction may not be necessary but I **do think** that it is necessary.  Things like state and history are both going to use both.  I'm not sure about transaction gossip.  I don't think that the "content" network will actually be the right tool for transaction gossip.  If that is true, then bundling them together means that tx gossip network doesn't end up using the "content" parts.

The reason I am not sure tx gossip will use the "content" network stuff is that data in that network doesn't "live" anywhere specific.  You don't go find a transaction the way you find a piece of state data or history.  Instead the transactions "flow" around the network freely but ephemerally and you as a node passively discover, receive, and propagate the transactions around the network.  For this we do still need something like uTP since transactions can exceed the UDP packet size, but we don't need FINDCONTENT/FOUNDCONTENT.

author: pipermerriam
content:
our functionality graph looks something like:

- overlay stands on its own
- uTP stands on its own
- content stands on top of overlay & uTP
- maybe a generic gossip protocol that stands on overlay and uTP (but I'm doubtful that this abstraction makes senses because tx gossip and header gossip both work very differently so doing them custom seems more appropriate)
